techniques.name: Palm Muting
techniques.description: Heavy palm muting technique essential for the authentic Enter Sandman sound, used throughout the main riff and rhythm sections.

notes: Rest palm lightly on bridge, maintaining consistent pressure
Too much pressure will completely mute strings - find the sweet spot
Use consistent downstrokes for power and attack
sequence: Place palm edge on bridge near saddles
tips: Practice slowly to develop consistent palm pressure
Focus on the low E and A strings for maximum impact
Combine with power chord shapes for full effect
details.progression: Em - Em/D pattern with palm muting

techniques.name: Power Chord Progressions
techniques.description: Foundation power chord progressions using root and fifth intervals, providing the harmonic structure for verse and chorus sections.

notes: Use only root and fifth for maximum power and clarity
Mute unused strings to avoid unwanted noise
Strong downstrokes for rhythmic emphasis
sequence: Form power chord shape (root on 6th string)
Mute remaining strings with fretting hand
tips: Keep fretting hand close to frets for clear notes
Use pick attack for aggressive sound
Practice smooth transitions between chord changes

techniques.name: String Bending
techniques.description: Lead guitar technique featuring controlled string bending for expressive solo phrases, primarily in the 12th-15th fret area using E minor pentatonic scale.

notes: Use multiple fingers for support during bends
Focus on accurate pitch - aim for specific intervals
Combine with vibrato for sustained notes
sequence: Position in 12th fret E minor pentatonic box
Use ring finger for primary bends
Support with middle and index fingers
Apply controlled pressure for half-step or whole-step bends
tips: Practice bending to pitch with a tuner
Start with lighter gauge strings if struggling

sections.name: Intro/Main Riff
sections.description: The iconic opening riff that defines the song, featuring heavy palm muting on the low E string with syncopated rhythm patterns.
sections.progression: Em - Em/D (i chord with bass note variation)
notes: Heavy palm muting throughout the entire riff
Emphasize downstrokes for maximum attack
Keep tempo steady at 123 BPM
Focus on the syncopated rhythm pattern

sections.name: Verse
sections.description: Verse section featuring Em-C chord progression with lighter palm muting, allowing chords to ring more than the intro.
notes: Lighter palm muting than intro section
Let chords ring more for harmonic content
Maintain steady strumming pattern
Emphasize chord changes on beat one

sections.name: Pre-Chorus
sections.description: Building tension section that returns to heavy palm muting, creating dynamic contrast before the chorus.
notes: Gradual dynamic increase building to chorus
Return to heavy palm muting technique
Maintain rhythmic precision
Create tension through repetition

sections.name: Chorus
sections.description: Main chorus featuring the complete Em-C-G-D-Em progression with full power chord voicings and open strumming.
sections.progression: Em - C5 - G5 - D5 - Em (i - ♭VI - ♭III - ♭VII - i)
notes: Full volume with open strumming
Emphasize chord changes with strong attacks
No palm muting - let chords ring fully
Create sense of resolution returning to Em

sections.name: Bridge
sections.description: Bridge section featuring C-G-D-Em progression with cleaner tone and arpeggiated approach.
notes: Cleaner tone compared to other sections
Arpeggiated or lighter strumming approach
Focus on harmonic movement
Creates contrast before guitar solo

sections.name: Guitar Solo
sections.description: Lead guitar solo featuring E minor pentatonic scale in the 12th-15th fret area with string bending and vibrato techniques.
sections.progression: E minor pentatonic scale patterns over Em chord
notes: Primary position: 12th fret E minor pentatonic box
Focus on string bending accuracy and vibrato
Use multiple fingers for bending support
Combine legato and picked notes for variety

sections.name: Outro
sections.description: Return to the main riff with variations, gradually fading out while maintaining the heavy palm-muted character.
sections.progression: Em - Em/D (return to main riff pattern)
notes: Return to main riff with slight variations
Gradual dynamic decrease for fade out
Maintain heavy palm muting throughout
Keep consistent tempo until final fade

guitar.pickup: EMG 81/60 active humbuckers or high-output passive humbuckers

effects.distortion: High-gain amp distortion preferred over pedals
effects.reverb: Minimal - studio reverb or short room reverb
effects.other: Noise gate recommended for tight palm-muted sections

steps: Learn basic Em and C chord shapes
Work on chord transitions between Em and C

Create your own variations and improvisations

commonMistakes: Too much palm pressure causing complete string muting
Inconsistent picking attack leading to uneven rhythm
Rushing the tempo during the main riff
Not muting unused strings during power chord sections
practiceRoutine: Start with palm muting exercises at slow tempo
Practice main riff slowly with metronome
Work on chord transitions between sections
Practice solo phrases individually before combining
Play along with original recording for timing
metronomeWork: Begin practicing main riff at 80-90 BPM
Gradually increase tempo to full speed (123 BPM)
Use metronome clicks on beats 1 and 3 for emphasis
Practice with subdivision clicks for complex rhythms
Work on staying locked with metronome during palm-muted sections
